awd_titl_txt: Modernizing Traditional Medicine and the Law
awd_abstract_narration:
Traditional forms of knowledge about bioactive plants have challenged current legal and scientfic understandings of intellectual property (IP) by raising questions about the centrality of authorship, the definition of property, the obligations of ownership, and the territoriality of the patent system. Understanding how these forms of knowledge can productively intersect with global IP regimes is an important question for policymakers, social scientists, and those seeking to fairly distribute IP benefits to traditional groups. To address this issue, this study investigates how and why scientists and scientific institutions investigating traditional medicine in Africa are innovating new sustainable forms of intellectual property as the grace periods for the implementation of the major international property agreements near their end and developing countries are compelled to complete the transition to the new global property regime. The study investigates the formation and operation of new forms of collaboration that are emerging between healers, patients, scientists, scientific institutions and private companies in the name of modernizing traditional medicine; accounts for the relationship between property and health that inheres in visions of sustainable health; and describes the forms of commons that are being imagined in efforts to develop traditional medicine with the goal of contributing to sustainable health. To do so, the study uses ethnographic tools to examine the ways that two research centers in Tanzania are interpreting, applying and re-working global intellectual property policies during their research into traditional medicines.  

Broader impacts include the creation of international research and publication networks, educational and capacity building initiatives, and transferrable knowledge about how traditional forms of knowledge can be fairly integrated into international property regimes. This project will also bring African ways of knowing and innovating into emerging legal debates on property, public domain, and the commons in an effort to catalyze new possibilities for the protection of plant life and communal knowledge derived from plant life.

por.por_cntn:
This project, Toward Sustainable Health: Modernizing Traditional Medicine and the Law in Tanzania, examined the commercialization of plant-based therapeutic products in Tanzania. During the my fieldwork, I sought to account for the kinds of commodities modern "traditional medicines" might be, the forms of efficacy they articulate, the conceptualizations of knowledge they coordinate, the sorts of property they enable, and the institutional and interpersonal relations they build. The core of the ethnography rests on twenty months of fieldwork (between 2012-2017) investigating the commercialization of therapeutic foods and medicinal herbs in Tanzania. The NSF-funded fieldwork was conducted in northern Tanzania. I investigated some of the most prominent actors contributing to the researching, developing and regulating of therapeutic plants (e.g., National Institute of Medical Research, the Business Registration and Licensing Agency, the Tanzanian Food and Drug Authority, and the University of Dar es Salaam, as well as hospital-based practitioners and their patients) and international organizations whose work has shaped Tanzanian possibilities in this field (e.g., Slow Food International, the World Health Organization, and the World Intellectual Property Organization). In addition, I spent hundreds of hours sitting and talking with those in pain and illness and those offering plants as a way to move through the debilitating moment. I observed the production of therapies, participated in the spread of plants, and tracked both the geographical and affective dimensions of the dissemination of therapies. When necessary I used other funds to follow up on the leads in this work and traveled to Kenya, South Africa, The Netherlands, Germany and Italy for short fieldwork periods in order to understand the pressures on actors in Tanzania. My analysis and writing draw on 214 recorded interviews and focus groups, as well as extensive field notes from more than 1,000 hours of observation in clinics and organizations growing, producing, selling therapeutic plants in Tanzania.

One of the most significant arguments emerging from my analysis is that the development and commercialization of therapeutic plants, particularly a new configuration of plant-based healing know as ?nutritious medicines? (or dawa lishe), is driven by a concern with the toxicity. For Tanzanians, modern bodies bear complicated toxic loads not only because of the dumping of capitalism?s harmful byproducts, but also because of the very products that facilitate domestic life (e.g., plastics, kerosene), agriculture (e.g., pesticides, chemical fertilizers) and health (e.g., antiretrovirals, contraceptives). Dawa lishe (nutritious medicine) is forged in this double-bind. These plant therapies heal by feeding, nourishing, strengthening, supporting bodies, bringing vitality, stimulating growth, enabling endurance. Treatments attend not only to individual bodies, but also to relations between people, plants and soil.

Dawa lishe is not a return to, or even a nostalgia for, ?traditional? African healing. It is, however, a refusal to forget in the present that African healing has long addressed humans and their environments together. Efforts to produce dawa lishe share a kinship with the rise of various projects in Africa and throughout the South that draw local knowledge of how to support the flourishing of plants and people, together with a range of global ecological and health movements. As such they contribute to what Michelle Murphy (2017) has called the "experimental otherwise."

Producers and users of dawa lishe are experimenting with ways to inhabit the toxicities that simultaneously enable contemporary life and deplete the very conditions of its ongoing-ness. They strive to cultivate and extend the forms of strength that make places, times and bodies livable again. In so doing, they raise critical questions about the temporalities of illness and healing and the matters of toxin and remedy, as well as the politics of how they structure care.

Insofar as power rests in the constitution of objects of concern and care ? that is, of those things about which knowledge might be generated, value created, law mobilized, time marked, and history told ? tracking the emergence of dawa lishe, suggests a way to account for the workings of power ethnographically. I am currently working on a book from this research under the working title, Medicines that Feed Us: Plants, Healing, and Sovereignty in a Toxic World. In this work, I examine how dawa lishe translates and (re)configures notions of medicine, property, chronicity and crisis that are fundamental to global health. I argue that in the process of exploring that which is required to sustain, to endure, and to thrive, Tanzanian herbal producers are articulating a politics of habitability that challenges the properties of therapeutic and economic value that drive the pharmaceuticalization of health.
